ratings.comment: I loved Prof Clayton! Clearly cares about her students and archaeology. She would give us extra credit sometimes just for showing up (after st paddy's) or answering questions during lecture. Can't recommend her enough. Her class is only based on 4 things, but they aren't super difficult.
i love sarah clayton

Absolute sweetheart. Just exudes good vibes in lecture, super nice. Exams aren't too difficult, and you are given a list of topics to focus on. Only 3 assignments through the semester, clearly outlined and feedback given.

Great lectures, interesting material, very fair tests (she makes it quite clear what will be on the exams). Professor Clayton is kind, knowledgeable, and clearly wants you to learn and succeed. Zero complaints.
Pretty easy class, not a lot of homework besides the readings that are not super necessary but definitely good to know and honestly pretty interesting - 2 papers and 2 exams in the semester

No lecture attendance, but discussions are required. Really great professor, covers material well, genuinely interested in students. Very passionate about the subject. Textbook readings are on the exam, not too detailed. Posts slides at the end of the week but those aren't the most comprehensive to what was discussed in class. Showing up is enough.

Good lord I hated this class. Lectures were so dry and all she wants to talk about is her research. The assignments are pretty easy and basically rambling until you hit a page count. Exams were fine, some niche questions but overall pretty easy if you do the study guides she gives.

Should have been the easiest class of my life. She's the kind of teacher who asks random stuff she mentions in lecture once for a minute, and expects you to know it. So if your not memorizing every little detail in every slide, it doesn't matter how much you study, you will always miss 6-8 questions. I would not take any class with her ever again.

I enjoyed Professor Clayton, 102 is a class taught by 4 professors and she was probably my second/third favorite. I would recommend going to class because that is where most of the info is given and you may be sort of lost if you don't go, but I know a lot of people don't. She was the only professor to give extra credit in the class.

This class was actually pretty interesting, and I am not even an Anthropology major. This class is graded by very few things, so make sure when tests come around, you actually have a clue about what's going on. Overall pretty good class and professor!

I really enjoyed Dr. Clayton's class. There are only two papers and two tests, but no final. The discussion sections with her TA flowed perfectly with her lecture, but make sure to go to them. She loves to talk about her experiences as an archaeologist and connect them to the lecture. I definitely recommend this class with Dr. Clayton.

A kind and enthusiastic professor. Her lectures include a lot of info that's not on the slides, so I recommend going even though attendance isn't taken. The lectures are interesting and easy to understand. She is also responsive to emails and was willing to boost my grade that was just below the cutoff for an A due to missing a couple discussions.

Anthro 212 with her was interesting yet easy. I never felt anxious about assignments and she outlines clearly what will be on the exam. She wraps lots of her own experiences into the content. Discussions were probably my favorite class of the week because everything was so hands on. I highly recommend this class and Professor Clayton.

Prof. Clayton seems like the sweetest person ever. She is very passionate about what she teaches, and talks a lot about her personal experiences in the archaeological field, which makes lectures fun and interesting. The class is relatively easy- there are two main papers and the only other grades are for exams. I loved having her as my professor.

Dr. Clayton is funny and makes lecture interesting. The course was graded on four things (two assignments, two exams). Attendance in lecture wasn't mandatory, but on some days when few people showed up, she gave extra credit points to those who did. ANTHRO 212 is a great intro class for freshmen. Discussion was fun, too!

I loved Prof. Clayton's lectures. She seems super excited about the material which makes it easy to pay attention. She does have some assigned readings for her section of the course which are the focus during tests, but they are short and doable. Would highly recommend.

Prof. Clayton gave some of the most engaging and inspiring lectures that I have attended at UW. Her passion for archaeology really shines through, and her desire to share that passion is very apparent. Assignments were straightforward and graded fairly, and the weekly quizzes required some effort but were a good recap of lecture.

She was 1 of 5 lecturers and was very knowledgeable of the material. She assigned a couple, very long videos along with readings that needed to be read in order to do well on her exam. I wasn't interested in the readings, but she had short lectures that were more engaging. Overall, she was a good professor who cared about her students!

Prof. Clayton is an amazing professor. Her lectures were entertaining and informative, her discussion projects were clear and actually reflected what we did in lecture, and she would often turn class towards her student's needs instead of the curriculum. Overall the class was easy enough to get an A, but engaging enough to not waste time going to.

Dr. Clayton was 1 of 5 instructors for Anthro 102 and was my second favorite (behind Nam Kim). She has what I found to be the most interesting subject area to cover, and finds a way to make it very interesting and relatable to modern times. Would take again.

She is very passionate about her field and incorporates a lot of examples from her experience to contextualize concepts. The class itself was not too difficult and textbook readings were not all that important but were still fairly easy.

The most interesting, educated, and caring professor ever! Fascinating lectures where you actually learn - unlike some professors she doesn't overwhelm you with information. So well educated and works at such a cool site! She is so passionate, and you should visit her office hours just to learn more! Textbook not unused, but not extremely used.

Intro to Archaeology was super fun with Clayton-- I didn't know if I'd like the class, but it ended up being my favorite one this semester. Her tests were super easy and surface-level. If you follow assignment directions, you can easily get 100% on them. Coming to discussion and participating is mandatory. Lectures are all you need, didn't use text
Interesting material. Exams are fair. Good lecturer.

She seemed to really enjoy teaching and was overall good to listen to.  But she showed too many videos, that were really not as helpful as it would have been had she just put together a lecture on the material; especially as the material was on the test

An amazing professor! Her lectures are interesting and she encourages students' participation (although it's not required) and is open and humble to them. We were assigned lots of intense readings, but as long as you know the main idea you're fine. For a required Archaeology course for the Anthro major, I learned a lot and enjoyed what I learned.
Take this class: you will enjoy it!  My only complaint is that the content of Prof Clayton's exams is mostly vapid and tests your ability to memorize trivial facts.
She is extremely nice and makes the class interesting.

Clayton was an excellant professor. She really enjoyed teaching her section on Mesoamerica and Andean South America. Lecture with her was fun; attendance is mandatory. Her exam, along with Schroeder's material, was difficult, but doable. It has two essays and a map and some mult choice and matching. Study most for the essays and the map.
She's a good professor. Cares about her field of work and her students. Straight forward, easy exams. Don't need to buy the text book or go to class to get an A, pp slides online. Go to discussion.
Prof Clayton is a great professor. Super easy class, very fair grading. Got a 99% on the first midterm. There are only 4 papers you have to write during the semester. Its really interesting and fun.

You can tell Prof. Clayton is very enthusiastic about archaeology. Talking to her about honors paper in her office hour is a plus in this class. Assignments are not hard but you need to put a little effort into them.
My favorite class of the semester, it wasn't very difficult and she let you know exactly what needed to be known to do well in the class or on every exam. I'm a Zoo major and even loved this!

She is wonderful! I went in with an interest in archaeology, came out realizing it wasn't for me, but she still got across some great ideas and I'm still very happy I took this class. It is not hard at all. You can tell she sincerely cares and is knowledgeable.
I am in love with this woman.

I actually had Professor Clayton for two classes, Anthro 490 and Anthro 322. She alters her style for seminars and lectures, which is refreshing. Great person, completely friendly, passionate and humble. I continue to visit her during office hours even though I haven't taken a class with her for a year.

Also had her for 112. Great, energetic and helpful. Uses great examples and is always willing to talk to you outside of class if you want to discuss things or have questions. She is the light of my life.
Amazing.

This is a really great intro to anthro class.  Professor Clayton does a great job during lecture, it's obvious she has sound footing on the subject despite her new-ness to the university. Some studying is required, but if you go to lecture and take notes you'll be good to go.  On top of it all Clayton has a rockin' body, those legs drive me insane.
